docs.lead_paragraph: FOR a couple of days in 1998, when I should have been working, I was swept up reading Michael Cunningham's Pulitzer Prize-winning novel, ''The Hours.'' I read it after breakfast, when deadlines were looming. I read it on the subway heading to and from a concert. I actually finished it on a bench in my gym's locker room; I was so close to the end, I couldn't stop. Because I was so strongly affected by the novel, I was wary when I heard that the director Stephen Daldry was turning it into a film. How do you transfer such a powerfully interior book to the screen? But the reviews, over all, were excellent. So I went to the film the night in late December that it opened in New York.

docs.lead_paragraph: ''NEVER trust anyone over 30'' may be, in the real world, a slogan of prehistoric youth culture, but in quite a few recent movies it has the ring of prudent, if somewhat exaggerated, advice. A young person making his (or, less frequently, her) way in, let's say, the C.I.A., a big-city police department or the criminal underworld would be wise to doubt the good intentions of the middle-aged, in particular of those middle-aged men who serve as designated teachers, supervisors or mentors. In Ron Shelton's latest, ''Dark Blue,'' for example, an innocent, eager young detective played by Scott Speedman is initiated, by his older partner (Kurt Russell) and his own uncle (Brendan Gleeson), into a corrupt, violent and racist cabal within the L.A.P.D. The young man's integrity, his soul and his very life are endangered by his would-be protectors' vicious and amoral code of conduct. Mr. Speedman's predicament is reminiscent of Ethan Hawke's character's in ''Training Day'' (whose screenwriter, David Ayer, also wrote ''Dark Blue''). In that picture, a young policeman's induction into an elite anti-narcotics unit became a nightmare of shakedowns, drug abuse and general lawlessness conjured up by his garrulous, sociopathic senior partner, a role for which Denzel Washington won an Oscar.
docs.abstract: A O Scott article discusses movies in which older men in positions of authority betray younger men; cites dozen examples; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: FRANCES McDORMAND recently asked her husband, the filmmaker Joel Coen, to help her think about her work. She had finished a two-month Off Broadway run in Caryl Churchill's apocalyptic play ''Far Away'' and was feeling stymied. ''I told him that I wasn't sure what I needed to do now,'' she said, speaking in their home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. A good husband understands a woman's needs, and Mr. Coen didn't hesitate. ''He said, 'I think you should be the bad guy.' ''

docs.lead_paragraph: Movie history isn't made only on the screen. Still photographs, posters and other memorabilia offer insight into a film's craftsmanship as well as its social and political relevance. Here is a sampling of museums and special exhibitions devoted to film. GUGGENHEIM MUSEUM -- Between 1994 and 2002 Matthew Barney explored the process of creation in his epic ''Cremaster'' cycle: five feature-length films that unfold through complementary photographs, drawings, sculptures and installations. In ''Matthew Barney: The Cremaster Cycle,'' through June 11 at the museum, the artist has designed a site-specific installation centered on a five-channel video monitor suspended in the museum's rotunda. Each channel shows segments from ''Cremaster 3,'' shot in the Guggenheim. The full films are also being screened. On Fifth Avenue at 89th Street in Manhattan; 212-423-3500 or www.guggenheim.org.

docs.lead_paragraph: Walter Scharf, a film score composer and arranger who received 10 Academy Award nominations and worked on more than 200 movies and television programs, including ''Funny Girl,'' ''Mission: Impossible'' and ''White Christmas,'' died on Monday at his home here. He was 92. Born in New York, Mr. Scharf came to Los Angeles in 1934 as an arranger for Rudy Vallee's orchestra. Through the 1930's he wrote incidental music for more than a dozen films.

docs.lead_paragraph: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show. + means discounted tickets were at the Theater Development Fund's TKTS booth for performances last Friday and Saturday nights. Broadway + ''FRANKIE AND JOHNNY IN THE CLAIR DE LUNE.'' Rosie Perez, who took over from Edie Falco in Terrence McNally's comic drama of lonely souls in the big city, is a lively, sexy and engaging actress. But are such attributes virtues in ''Frankie and Johnny''? On one level, after all, the play can be described as a story of two people who are lucky to have found each other because it's clear that no one else would sleep with either one. And while this might hold true for the crazy-eyed, leering interpretation of Johnny by Joe Pantoliano (who replaced Stanley Tucci), Ms. Perez's feisty, saucy Frankie hardly comes across as the vulnerable loner that Ms. Falco was. As Ms. Perez and Mr. Pantoliano swap confessions, insults and declarations, the show develops the jittery seesaw rhythms of a sitcom. This is a breezy ''Frankie and Johnny'' that elicits easy laughs but not empathetic tears (2:20). Belasco, 111 West 44th Street, (212) 239-6200. Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays at 8 p.m.; Wednesdays and Saturdays at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sundays at 3 p.m. Tickets: $21.25 to $81.25 (Ben Brantley).

Until 2001, that is, when Baz Luhrmann's ''Moulin Rouge'' took off as a musical odyssey into postmodern techno-pastiche (19th-century Paris, 20th-century pop-rock, 21st-century camerawork).

docs.snippet: Among the early front-runners for major Oscar nominations, Sam Mendes's ''Road to Perdition'' was passed in the home stretch by the likes of ''The Pianist'' and ''Gangs of New York.'' In 1999 Mr. Mendes's first feature film, ''American Beauty,'' w...
docs.lead_paragraph: Among the early front-runners for major Oscar nominations, Sam Mendes's ''Road to Perdition'' was passed in the home stretch by the likes of ''The Pianist'' and ''Gangs of New York.'' In 1999 Mr. Mendes's first feature film, ''American Beauty,'' won in the best film, director and actor categories, but this time the only ''Perdition'' contender for the so-called big six Oscars is Paul Newman as best supporting actor for his portayal of the mob boss John Rooney. But as we see on a fine DVD released this week by DreamWorks, the real strength of the film turns up further along the list of categories: art direction, cinematography, sound, sound editing and original score. ''Road to Perdition'' was nominated in all five.
docs.abstract: Home Video column on DVD release of Sam Mendes's Road to Perdition and The Mystic Masseur; Ismail Merchant comments on adaptation of V S Naipaul novel (S)

docs.snippet: IN Brazil, Fernando Altério is known as Mr. Showbiz. He produces concerts by musical stalwarts like Gilberto Gil, Chico Buarque and Caetano Veloso, a singer and a songwriter who has a musical cameo in Pedro Almodóvar's movie ''Talk to Her.''    ...
docs.lead_paragraph: IN Brazil, Fernando Altério is known as Mr. Showbiz. He produces concerts by musical stalwarts like Gilberto Gil, Chico Buarque and Caetano Veloso, a singer and a songwriter who has a musical cameo in Pedro Almodóvar's movie ''Talk to Her.'' After the encores, Mr. Altério, 50, likes to take the backstage entourage home with him. The post-concert parties at his home here in Jardim Europa, an elegant neighborhood with houses tucked behind walls, rarely start before midnight. Mr. Altério's two-story living room plays center stage to a loungey, laid-back scene with a mix of musicians, friends and models, who linger over Scotch and Champagne as late as 5 a.m. A white archway acts as a giant proscenium framing a recessed dining area. Above the arch is a balcony, where guests can scan the crowd. When Mr. Altério slides open a wall of 21-foot-tall glass doors mounted on wheels, the vast living room becomes a giant open-air porch. Strains of Brazilian jazz follow the guests as they spill out into a courtyard garden that has a lap pool with a wall of smooth pebbles as a backdrop.

docs.lead_paragraph: Daniel Taradash, who won a screenwriting Oscar for ''From Here to Eternity,'' died here on Saturday. He was 90. Mr. Taradash attended Harvard University and received a law degree in 1936 from Harvard Law School. Though he passed the New York State bar, he never practiced law, deciding instead to become a writer.
